You can get an amazing MTO boot for $250-700, brand new. Let's go for the max price here, $700. Avoid the prestige trap money pit "big names", do 30 mins of research.

Let's assume the average reader is 25 years old and will die at 80. And let's say they have to resole the boot three times at $150 each over the course of their life. So one pair of boots, life time cost is $1150. Over 55 years that's $21/yr for one pair of boots.

Now let's say he gets a cheap pair of boots for $100, and they last three years. They won't, but let's pretend. That works out to $33.34/yr, for shitty boots.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Demeter fragrances blind buy.
2 keepers, 2 for birthday gifts, and 5 that won't be used much - if at all. Will not be buying any of these again. I sampled these all last night. Took a long shower afterwards. My nose was burning and I had a headache.
Listed from best to worst:

>Amber
sweet and spicy, creamy, earthy, warm.
vanilla, dry woods, incense, spices, some very light citrus - i think its orange

>Pineapple
pineapple juice. sweet and syrupy
its really strong.

>Cedar
old dusty cedar boards. something lemony and bitter, a little earthy

>Hawaiian Vanilla
sweet vanilla with a hint of coconut
suntan lotion or a 'tropical' scented body cream

>Pipe Tobacco
sweet and spicy, woody, smokey. its definitely pipe tobacco. becomes dryer and ashier over time
theres a very faint metallic cherry scent that you get with almond extract

>Pistachio Ice Cream
pistachio ice cream, pistachio pudding, pistachio cookies

>Sandalwood
sweet, soapy, powdery sandalwood
smells like an air freshener

>Pink Grapefruit
bitter grapefruit peels, soapy, medicinal
'citrus' scented cleaning solution

>Russian Leather
dirty leather couch, old books, and an ash tray

>>17471764
The question is not why punk, goth, etc. died - the cycle of subcultures' birth, absorption into the capitalist mainstream, and death has been well documented since the days of the greasers, hippies, and mods (see Adam Curtis or Dick Hebdige's work). The question is why new ones have failed to emerge.

But obviously new subcultures have emerged post-2000. I mean you could consider 4chan it's own subculture, we have our own vernacular and distinct set of cultural reference points. And there have been plenty of cults that form around various other websites, like LessWrong.

But what's the point of associating yourself with some internet subculture IRL? Earlier subcultures were regional by necessity, you didn't see some town with one single punk or hippy dude, they formed around some scene based in a physical location like a venue and spread from there. Dressing up meant excluding yourself from normal society to satisfy the scene's gatekeeping standards, it was a real cost of admission where you gave up access to some things to gain access to others, classic tribal shit. Subcultures online can't impose any IRL gatekeeping of that sort, so fashion has simply not been part of the program.

This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

I had a pair of Momotaro jeans and they were amazing. They shrank in the wash and i gained weight so i had to get rid of them which sucked
You could buy any one of those brands and be satisfied. They're all on an extremely high level of quality. Iron Heart specifically does super heavy denim. That's their niche, but that doesn't mean the rest aren't every bit as good
Samurai is amazing and will probably be my next pair. Pure Blue Japan is also really interesting. Honestly just look at the brands and find what you think you'll like and go for it. You can't go wrong

>>17469373
>Sport coats

If you've never gotten into them before, either have a friend measure you or paid a tailor 20 bucks to do it. I'd go to the tailor because you're going to probably need to build a relationship with one eventually

Here are the measurements you need in descending importance:

1 Shoulders
2 Chest
3 Waist
4 Sleeves

Shoulders will fuck your fit up and can not be adjusted. Remind yourself of this dozens of times. If your shoulders are 18", you can wear sport coats that are 18-19". Anything too small won't fit, and anything too large will look awful and you can't really cheat around it by adding bulky layers either.

Chest and waist are way easier to work with, if it's a couple inches big they can be taken in. I am cheap and want to avoid the tailor because I am also lazy so I am for sport coats that have a few inches drop between chest and west to emphasize my torso and make me look less like a sack of potatoes. If my chest is 45, I want my waist on the coat to be 41-42. Nothing massive because I'm not in great shape.
Note that this isn't my actual waist, that's a 36.

Sleeves are normally easy to deal with. If they are too long, hem them. If they are a little short don't panic, there's normally an inch built in for adjustment.

Once you have those measurements it's just a matter of patience on eBay. Search for your chest, and then match your measurements from the tailor with the measurements provided by the seller.

>>17469555
>Haha, i like them billowy like that. Its just a full cut, not the wrong size - the neck, armholes, and cuffs fit well.

For the record, that can still be the wrong size. I'm the guy giving sport coat sizing advice, didn't want to go into too much at once and make things more complicated than needed but here's so more info:

My chest is 42", but my neck is 16.5" and it's snug at 16.5. My sleeve length is 36. So if I blindly buy a 16.5x36 dress shirt, the body often billows because my powerful lizard like neck is meant to be with a size 46 to 48 shirt for the chest measurement.

I'm 6'3 and about 215, but even when I was 150 and so much hotter my neck size was still the same. What to do?

1: Buy shirts from retailers like Charles Tyrwhitt that let you choose "cuts". I get a 16.5x36 extra slim. That way my neck isn't choked, but the torso is thinner and so are the sleeves

2: Buy a shirt that fits torso and use collar extenders. It's basically an invisible button with an elastic loop that you attach to your collar button, increases the collar size by an inch. If you're wearing a tie, it's invisible. If you're not wearing a tie, don't button the top button, and then you're fine.

3: Made to measure shirts. This is where I'm gravitating towards now that I get the process and know where to go. This way the shirt will be designed to fit you perfectly

>>17471991
Ok here's where it gets dicey. Oftentimes when we have someone who strongly inspires us, the urge is to copy them as much as possible. Imitation is flattering, etc. The problem is a lot of people in the beginning of their style evolution didn't stop to think "Will this look as good on me as it does him?" And of equal importance "Do I have to the money to buy what I need to look good?"

I went to his insta and his look doesn't seem to revolve around items that fit a certain way, which is good. That way you can copy elements whether you have the same body as him or not. Do me a favor, go to his Instagram and pic out any fit there, then we're going to see what you could take from it and make your own without looking like you're trying to cosplay him.

OP here. A few things in response to this. Please read, my fellow /fa/ anons:
Factors Contributing to my Decision to Purchase this Hugo Boss T Shirt for ~$80CAD (at 60% off retail btw), an Essay
Part 1:
>For that price, it better be 100% good quality cotton
It is 100% cotton and it is also mercerized, which is a chemical process that alters the physical properties of cotton. Mercerization makes the dye fade less easily and also adds lustre and softness. The extra labour required for this process does add some to the final retail price. Beyond that, I don’t know anything about the origin or quality of the particular raw material cotton used in manufacture of this garment.

That stepper motor is properly fucking retarded. I've seen these before in like early Ronda movements.

It's especially embarrassing for the Swiss, that the Japanese already had proper stepper motors figured out already in the beginning. Pic related is my Seiko 3803, the 38xx series was Seiko's very first actual mass-production quartz movements. You can't go any further back in time than that without shelling out ridiculous money for a Seiko quartz that was made only in like 10000 units, or 1000, or a 100 (yeah, Seiko had production runs like that for their first quartz movements). But already you have the now-common motor layout.

Also I wonder if that Tissot has a Motorola chip. In the early days watch manufacturers didn't have chip manufacturing set up yet, so they bought the frequency-divider chips from companies like Motorola.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17472177
I'm a big fan of Japanese watches, especially Orient and Seiko. But i wouldn't recommend a Bambino if you're willing to fork out 700-800 for a dressy watch.
With that kind of money you can get a dressy, but still somewhat casual Certina or Tissot model (leather strap, or bracelet). I like the Visodate, but you can go for one without the day of the week indicator, lots of models, so i encourage you to browse those two brands in particular.
There's any Hamilton Jazzmaster (tho i don't like them personally).

But if you're looking to go cheaper i think it boils down to Bambino vs Cocktail time.
Both are beautiful, the Seikos have an edge, but they are more expensive. It boils down to "do i need this 100-150$ , should i use it for something else, save it, or buy another watch". If the answer is "yes, yes, i could use that money for something else", then get the bambino you like the most. If you're willing to dish it out for one watch, get the cocktail time.
I find most models of both lines beautiful, but SRPH78J1 is a fucking stunner. It looks like it could easily cost 4-5 times more, and it's like 10$ more retail than the basic cocktail time (if your retailer has it, that is).
Or check out some Orient star models.
But 1000$ gives you a lot more options. The bambino is a no brainer if you have 500$ sitting around, and could maybe use some of that money next month.

As far as I'm concerned it's either in-house mechanical or just go quartz. Powermatic 80, Sellita SW200, whatever the fuck the Soprod is called are just copes for not being able to get an interesting movement.

I don't even have a watch with an in-house movement, the epiphany came to me when the PRX was offered with a Powermatic 80 for twice the price of the Quartz which offered
>Less accuracy
>Less power reserve
>Less durability
>Equally mass produced and soulless movement
>Would still throw the movement out rather than bother servicing or repairing if broken
>Thicker and heavier

I appreciate not every watch with an ETA clone or Seiko NH35 would suddenly become half price if they had a Quartz option, but I would absolutely take the Quartz version if offered.

The problem is tissot will have moved past the powermatic 80 in 10 or so years, after 20 or 30 the stocks will be depleted. Unless you pay out the ass for a very skilled watchmaker with proprietary tools to service it, the watch wont last beyond then.

A watch with a sellita or eta however can be serviced regularly on the cheap, and replacement parts will be produced for at least the next 50 years due to the sheer number of watches that use them, or derivatives of them.

It doesnt matter to most people, but if you want to pass a watch down to your grandson and don't want to pay rolex money, an sw200 or 2824 is your best bet

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17473015
You can get them on eBay probably but you’ll have to spend more time than average looking for the right size/condition.
You could also measure one of your pairs of Classic Fits - there will be many guides online telling you what key measurements you’ll need to take. Shouldn’t be more complicated than taking a ruler & jotting down the waist, hips, knees, & bottom hem. From there, you can look at the size guides to other comparable brands to see what pair has the closest fit to your Lees.
If you’re not against it, you can also go to your nearest mall/shopping center to try on a bunch of pairs and see what you like the best.

posts.com:
The more you get into something the more esoteric and abstract your taste becomes. Especially if you're hanging out with other people who are equally into that thing. All those people are going to be trying to one up and impress each other. It doesn't remotely make any sense that they would be wearing really basic and palatable stuff that the general public is into.

This happens with literally every single field on Earth its not strange or weird at all. It applies to everything from fashion to even the lamest most boring and corny shit I can think of like board games.

If you hang out with a bunch of people really into board games they're not going to be playing Monopoly. They're going to be busting out really weird discontinued board games with complicated and bizarre rules. Imagine going up to those people and telling them they should be playing Monopoly because that's what everyone likes. Nigga these mfers done finished with Monopoly now it's time for Twilight Imperium: Third Edition.

People deeply into fashion or anything else are exactly the same. They don't give a fuck what the general public is into.

Because pic related is the alternative. That's what happens when everyone tries to look as good as possible to as many people as possible. If you're really into this shit you don't care about looking good to NPC's. You're going to experiment and wear weird ass silhouettes and stuff that's objectively ugly to see if you can find some weird way to make it work. That's where all the fun and interest is. It's in the weird fucked up concepts and the stuff that's rough around the edges and has soul. Those are the things that are way more interesting to discuss and pursue. NOT trying to look good to as many people as possible. That's a solved equation and it's boring as shit. It's something for NPC's to concern themselves with.

Like I said this applies to all creative fields. You ask a professional artist what type of stuff inspires them they're not going to say the Mona Lisa lol they're probably going to say something weird and fucked up and objectively "shit" like Chris-Chans art or Tails Gets Trolled.

DHT is the main cause of hairloss because it's toxic to hair follicles. Generally your DHT increases when your T increases, but DHT levels still vary strongly from person to person. DHT sensitivity of the follicles in the scalp also varies from person to person.
So high T people are probably more likely to go bald, but that doesn't mean that all (or most) high T people go bald, or that people who are bald are high T, or that people who are low T don't go bald.
